articles.title: TCS‚Äô $6.5 bn bet marks India‚Äôs push against tech colonisation
articles.content: Agencies Tata Consultancy Services ( TCS ) has drawn up a $6.5 billion capital expenditure plan that goes beyond simply setting aside risk capital, Times of India reported. The move marks a deeper push to build long-term digital capabilities and potentially guard against what experts call ‚Äútech colonisation‚Äù. As India‚Äôs digital infrastructure demand surges, companies are turning to private capital to fund new capacity and build resilience in their technology networks. In an interview with ToI , TCS CEO K Krithivasan said the company aims to become ‚Äúthe world‚Äôs largest AI-led services company.‚Äù He said the initiative carries ‚Äúa strong India angle, alongside global opportunities with our existing clients.‚Äù On funding, Krithivasan said it would be ‚Äúa mix of equity and debt.‚Äù He added, ‚ÄúOn the equity side, we've partnered with a financial investor, giving us the flexibility and control to shape our growth path and decide who we work with‚Äîresulting in a stronger and more strategic business model.‚Äù Prateek Jhawar, managing director and head of infrastructure and real assets investment banking at Avendus Capital, said global investment institutions such as Apollo, Blackstone, and CPP Investments are structuring long-tenor debt backed by contracted hyperscaler cash flows. ‚ÄúRecent deals (Digital Realty's $7 billion JV with Blackstone, Aligned's $1.7 billion private credit raise, and EdgeCore's $1.9 billion financing) highlight how bespoke capital stacks are reshaping the ecosystem,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThe demand tailwinds are so strong that data centres are now being underwritten more like core infrastructure assets, not just technology real estate.‚Äù Jhawar said India‚Äôs total data centre capacity is expected to exceed 2,000 MW in the next two years, which would require an estimated $3.5 billion in additional investment. He added that operators such as AdaniConneX, Yotta Data, and CapitaLand have already raised a cumulative $2 billion to fund hyperscale campuses in Mumbai, Chennai, and Hyderabad. ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs changing is not just the volume of capital, but the nature of it,‚Äù Jhawar said. ‚ÄúFlexible private credit structures and long-dated infrastructure funds are now competing to anchor Indian digital infrastructure. For investors, this convergence of AI-led demand, predictable cash flows, and hard-asset characteristics is transforming data centres into the defining infrastructure story of the next decade.‚Äù A report by Barclays projected that India could attract about $19 billion in data centre investments by 2030, up from $12 billion last year. Sanjeev Dasgupta, CEO of CapitaLand Investment India, said India‚Äôs demand is being fuelled by two key segments‚Äîhyperscalers and large enterprise customers such as banks, financial institutions, and stock exchanges. ‚ÄúBoth are growing fast, but hyperscalers are expanding faster due to AI plans in India and other markets,‚Äù he said. Live Events Dasgupta said, ‚ÄúWe are building roughly about 245‚Äì250 MW of gross load. Our planned capex is about $1 billion, which is being incurred as projects get built.‚Äù He added that many US and other foreign companies establishing large data centre projects in India are taking two approaches. ‚ÄúSome have bought large land parcels and are going for self-builds, while others are leasing space from existing operators,‚Äù he said. Ramkumar Ramamoorthy, partner at tech growth advisory firm Catalincs, said this period represents a rare inflection point for Indian technology firms. ‚ÄúWith hundreds of billions of dollars tied to opportunities created by structural shifts in technology, this is the moment for companies to reinvest their margin dollars back into their businesses and leap into the future instead of playing by yesterday‚Äôs rules,‚Äù he said. Ramamoorthy added, ‚ÄúFollowing TCS' footsteps, I hope a consortium of cash-rich companies will invest in building India‚Äôs much-needed compute, AI, cloud, and cyber infrastructure‚Äîand benefit from it‚Äîrather than leaving this critical task largely to the government. If we don‚Äôt act now and scale rapidly, we risk missing a generational opportunity and enabling digital colonization‚Äîa future where we remain dependent on others for our technology needs and opportunities.‚Äù Add as a Reliable and Trusted News Source Add Now! articles.summary: Agencies Tata Consultancy Services ( TCS ) has drawn up a $6. 5 billion capital expenditure plan that goes beyond simply setting aside risk capital, Times of India reported. The move marks a deeper push to build long-term digital capabilities and potentially guard against what experts call ‚Äútech colonisation‚Äù.
